articles.headline: Obama Admits Web Site Flaws on Health Law
articles.snippet: President Obama offered an impassioned defense of the Affordable Care Act, acknowledging the technical failures of the HealthCare.gov Web site, but providing little new information about the problems.
articles.abstract: President Obama offered an impassioned defense of the Affordable Care Act, acknowledging the technical failures of the HealthCare.gov Web site, but providing little new information about the problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama offered an impassioned defense of the Affordable Care Act on Monday, acknowledging the technical failures of the HealthCare.gov Web site, but providing little new information about the problems with the online portal or the efforts by government contractors to fix it.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Netflix Hits Milestone and Raises Its Sights
articles.snippet: The video service said on Monday that it had surpassed 30 million U.S. subscribers and it reported third-quarter results that beat most expectations.
articles.abstract: The video service said on Monday that it had surpassed 30 million U.S. subscribers and it reported third-quarter results that beat most expectations.

articles.headline: An Odd Alliance in Patagonia
articles.snippet: The great potential of an oil field called Vaca Muerta, or Dead Cow, has united an American oil giant and a politically volatile country.
articles.abstract: The great potential of an oil field called Vaca Muerta, or Dead Cow, has united an American oil giant and a politically volatile country.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEUQUÉN, Argentina — On the windswept Patagonian steppe, crews of roughnecks are drilling around the clock in pursuit of a vast shale oil reservoir that might be the world’s next great oil field.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Economic Theory, via YouTube and Cartoon
articles.snippet: Ray Dalio, the founder of the largest hedge fund, offers a 30-minute lecture in how the economy works. No tuition necessary, just a connection to YouTube.
articles.abstract: Ray Dalio, the founder of the largest hedge fund, offers a 30-minute lecture in how the economy works. No tuition necessary, just a connection to YouTube.
articles.lead_paragraph: Forget Econ 101. Take a look at the lessons in Dalio 101.

articles.headline: Ruling Near, J.C. Penney Capitulates to Macy’s
articles.snippet: After a court suit from Macy’s claimed an exclusive contract with Martha Stewart, Penney scaled back its Stewart line as a court deadline appeared near.
articles.abstract: After a court suit from Macy’s claimed an exclusive contract with Martha Stewart, Penney scaled back its Stewart line as a court deadline appeared near.
articles.lead_paragraph: Days before a judge was expected to rule in the long-running legal dispute between Macy’s and J. C. Penney over the right to sell branded Martha Stewart housewares, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia and J. C. Penney scaled back the merchandising agreement at the center of the battle.

articles.headline: Sales Are Colossal, Shares Are Soaring. All Amazon Is Missing Is a Profit
articles.snippet: With gargantuan revenue, Amazon’s recent profits have been slim to nonexistent. In its quest to become the world’s bazaar, are earnings beside the point?
articles.abstract: With gargantuan revenue, Amazon’s recent profits have been slim to nonexistent. In its quest to become the world’s bazaar, are earnings beside the point?
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Nearly every day, Amazon announces a new venture.

articles.headline: Security Check Now Starts Long Before You Fly
articles.snippet: The T.S.A. has at its fingertips a large range of personal records to prescreen passengers, including past travel, property records and vehicle registrations.
articles.abstract: The T.S.A. has at its fingertips a large range of personal records to prescreen passengers, including past travel, property records and vehicle registrations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Transportation Security Administration is expanding its screening of passengers before they arrive at the airport by searching a wide array of government and private databases that can include records like car registrations and employment information.

articles.headline: In Clinton Fund-Raising, Expect a Full Embrace
articles.snippet: The Clintons in full fund-raising mode come as a revelation to donors accustomed to what some see as the aloof indifference of President Obama.
articles.abstract: The Clintons in full fund-raising mode come as a revelation to donors accustomed to what some see as the aloof indifference of President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a recent Manhattan fund-raiser for the Virginia candidate for governor Terry McAuliffe wound down and most of the donors had left the host’s swanky meatpacking district loft, President Bill Clinton stuck around.

articles.headline: Considering the Fairness of JPMorgan’s Deal
articles.snippet: As details emerge of a possible $13 billion settlement, Wall Street’s fears of a largely punitive settlement may not add up.
articles.abstract: As details emerge of a possible $13 billion settlement, Wall Street’s fears of a largely punitive settlement may not add up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some on Wall Street have portrayed JPMorgan Chase as a victim of government zealotry.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Civilian Deaths in Drone Strikes Cited in Report
articles.snippet: The study asserts that the C.I.A. drone campaign in Pakistan has at times killed civilians indiscriminately. In interviews, residents spoke of terror and strain within a society caught between militants and the drones.
articles.abstract: The study asserts that the C.I.A. drone campaign in Pakistan has at times killed civilians indiscriminately. In interviews, residents spoke of terror and strain within a society caught between militants and the drones.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the telling of some American officials, the C.I.A. drone campaign in Pakistan has been a triumph with few downsides: In more than 300 missile attacks there since 2008, dozens of Qaeda and Taliban leaders have been killed, and the pace of the strikes, which officials frequently describe as “surgical” and “contained,” has dropped sharply over the past year.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud

articles.headline: China Tries to Clean Up Toxic Legacy of Its Rare Earth Riches
articles.snippet: Export restrictions have done little to slow the devastation resulting from rare earth mining, including contamination that threatens the water supply of millions.
articles.abstract: Export restrictions have done little to slow the devastation resulting from rare earth mining, including contamination that threatens the water supply of millions.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — In northern China, near the Mongolian border, radioactively contaminated leaks from two decades of rare earth refining have been slowly trickling underground toward the Yellow River, a crucial water source for 150 million people.

articles.headline: Weak Job Gains May Cause Delay in Action by Fed
articles.snippet: A Labor Department report showing lackluster hiring in September — 148,000 jobs — is expected to further put off the Federal Reserve’s decision to reduce its stimulus efforts.
articles.abstract: A Labor Department report showing lackluster hiring in September — 148,000 jobs — is expected to further put off the Federal Reserve’s decision to reduce its stimulus efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before the federal government shutdown and debt ceiling crisis this month, the nation’s economy was lagging and job growth was sluggish. And the recent dysfunction in Congress seems likely to make the situation worse.
